content.description: Attendance records at a large high school show that <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> percent of students are late to school on a typical day. The students in an AP Statistics class believe the rate is higher than <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> percent. The students took a simple random sample of <math alttext="75" overflow="scroll"><mn>75</mn></math> students from the school and asked, “Were you late to school today?” In their sample, <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> out of the <math alttext="75" overflow="scroll"><mn>75</mn></math> students, or <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn></math> percent of the sample, said they were late to school that day. The AP Statistics students conducted a simulation with <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn></math> samples of <math alttext="75" overflow="scroll"><mn>75</mn></math> students from a population where <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> percent of students are late. The results of the simulation are shown in the dotplot.
content.question: Based on the simulation and the results of the AP Statistics class’s sample, is there convincing statistical evidence that more than <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> percent of all students at the school are late to school on a typical day?

choices.label: Yes, because <math alttext="8%" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of students in their sample said they were late to school that day.

Yes, because about <math alttext="47%" overflow="scroll"><mn>47</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the simulated sample percentages of students late to school are <math alttext="6%" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn><mo>%</mo></math> or more.

No, because about <math alttext="47%" overflow="scroll"><mn>47</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the simulated sample percentages of students late to school are <math alttext="6%" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn><mo>%</mo></math> or more.

Yes, because about <math alttext="29%" overflow="scroll"><mn>29</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the simulated sample percentages of students late to school are <math alttext="8%" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mo>%</mo></math> or more.

No, because about <math alttext="29%" overflow="scroll"><mn>29</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the simulated sample percentages of students late to school are <math alttext="8%" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mo>%</mo></math> or more.

content.answer: No, because about <math alttext="29%" overflow="scroll"><mn>29</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the simulated sample percentages of students late to school are <math alttext="8%" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mo>%</mo></math> or more.
